Graphical abstract This work reports the performance of low metal loading (about 3wt.%) Rh, Ni and Mo-Ni catalysts supported on carbon in the hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of phenol. The catalytic tests were carried out in a flow microreactor at 310°C and at a total hydrogen pressure of 3MPa. A commercial NiMoP/γ-Al2O3 sulfided catalyst was used as reference. The effect of catalyst pre-treatment (reduction against sulfidation) was investigated in the case of the noble metal catalyst. The thermally treated in inert atmosphere, fresh reduced and spent catalysts have been characterized by several physicochemical techniques: chemical analysis, N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms, Raman spectroscopy, Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM), X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and High Resolution Transmission Electron Microscopy (HRTEM). The HDO of phenol was found to be favored on the bifunctional Rh/C and Ni/AC catalysts which exhibit a large amount of well dispersed metallic species (from HRTEM). Contrary to a commercial sulfided NiMo/Al2O3 catalyst, the hydrogenation of aromatic ring of phenol was favored being the CO bond hydrogenolysis a minor reaction route. Catalytic HDO of phenol over Rh/C reveal that the catalyst activation by reduction is advantageous compared to that by sulfidation. The partial substitution of Ni by Mo in the Mo-Ni/AC catalyst led to enhance of the catalyst stability but decrease of overall activity occurs due to the decrease of amount of metallic nickel species. The role of the MoO3 species in the inhibition of deactivation by coke is discussed. Keywords Hydrodeoxygenation of phenol Carbon support Rh Ni Mo 1 Introduction The demand for energy worldwide is predicted to double before 2050 [1] as a result of population growth. Currently, fossil fuels account for over 85% of energy production. The combustion of fossil fuels produces CO2 emissions. CO2 emissions lead to environmental problems, including global warming. Thus, the global energy crisis [2] coupled with current environmental issues generates a serious problem. To overcome these challenges, renewable energy sources such as wind, solar, biomass, and hydroelectricity are being used increasingly. Biofuels are sustainable and have net zero carbon emissions. As a result, they appear to be a promising replacement for fossil fuels. However, the biofuel liquid produced from fast pyrolysis of biomass is rich in oxygen-containing compounds. Oxygen-containing compounds show the following negative properties: non-volatility, high viscosity, corrosiveness, poor heating value, thermal instability, and immiscibility with fossil fuels. To improve the properties of the biofuel liquid, oxygen can be removed using hydrodeoxygenation processes (HDO) [3]. Catalytic biomass conversion is developing extremely fast in recent years. Recent laboratory and commercial findings in the field of catalytic hydroprocessing of biomass liquefaction products are presented in a few excellent reviews [4–12]. A detailed survey of recent publications on Ni-based heterogeneous catalysts for energy and environmental applications was reported by De et al. [10] whereas recent advances in the design of metal-based nano-catalysts for de-functionalization of different biomass components was revised by Wang et al. [11]. For the Ni-based bimetallic systems, it was concluded that some reactions were favored and proceed on specific surfaces of the bimetallic catalysts, thus, the continued efforts on the rational design of surface of specific bimetallic catalysts are critical to achieve superior catalytic performances [10]. In this sense, the study of Zhang et al. [12] demonstrated that the bimetallic NiRu, NiRh and NiPd catalysts exhibited superior activity than corresponding monometallic counterparts in the hydrogenolysis of lignin CO bonds under low temperature (100°C) and low H2 pressure (1bar). However, although the conversion of lignocellulose, lipids, and chitin can be effectively catalyzed by well-defined nanocatalysts, it has been proposed that more studies are required to improve the synthesis procedure in order to extent their application from model reactions to real biomass conversion [11,12]. To perform HDO, a catalyst with high activity and stability is desired. Up to now, sulfided catalysts have been the main focus of biofuel HDO research. Published reports have shown that sulfided catalysts are not ideal for biofuel HDO because of their instability in the presence of H2O, contamination of product, and poor cost-effectiveness. As a result, current research has been redirected towards investigating sulfur-free catalysts. Noble metal catalysts offer exciting potential [4–10 and references within]. Under mild conditions noble metals are especially effective catalysts in the activation of molecular hydrogen. This is because without difficulty hydrogen can be activated and cleaved at the interface or surface to react with other reactants. Among the noble metals Rh is quite promising. The effect of support acidity on HDO activity of supported Rh-based catalysts was investigated using acidic substrates such as ZrO2 [13–17], Al2O3 [13,17], SiO2-Al2O3 [17]. The critical role of the support for the HDO of O-containing compounds is largely documented [4,18]. Alumina supports have been reported to produce large coke formations due to weak Lewis type acidic sites on the surface of the support [5]. In addition, the instability of the alumina support in the presence of the high levels of water was recognized as a serious shortcoming [19,20]. Thus, to prevent coke formation, a support of lower acidity and higher stability is necessary. In this sense, mesoporous carbon (C) and activated carbon (AC) are of interest because they possess these characteristics [5–13]. A very interesting study on the Rh/C catalyst was reported by Zhao et al. [21]. The catalyst activity of dual Rh/C and H3PO4 systems was evaluated in aqueous-phase hydrodeoxygenation of bio-derived phenols to cycloalkanes performed in a batch reactor at 200°C with a H2 pressure of 5MPa. In such conditions, hydrodeoxygenation of phenol proceeds via stepwise hydrogenation of the aromatic ring, transformation of the cyclic enol to the corresponding ketone, hydrogenation of the cycloalkanone to the cycloalkanol and its subsequent dehydration as well as the hydrogenation of the formed cycloalkene. The phenol conversion was 100% and the catalyst showed 92% selectivity toward cylohexane and 7% selectivity toward cylohexanone [21]. A comparison of the activity results of the Rh/C sample with Ru/C, Pt/C and Pd/C catalysts demonstrated that these four catalysts exhibited similar high activities (cyclohexane yields in the range 84–92%) in phenol conversion with H3PO4 at 200°C [21]. Studies concerning the use of carbon supports for HDO catalysts have been also reported for non-noble metals (e.g. Co, Ni, Mo). In this context, no coke formation during the HDO over sulfided CoMo/AC catalysts has been reported [5]. However, the extensive microporosity of active carbon is a drawback because part of the metals located in micropores is not accessible to large molecules involved in the reactants [22]. The influence of the active phase loading on the hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) activity of carbon-suported catalysts was investigated by Ferrari et al. [23]. It was found that the most important parameter for liquid phase HDO reaction of a mixture of model compounds (guaiacol, ethyldecanoate, 4-methylacetophenone) over sulfided CoMo/AC catalysts was the dispersion of the active phase. The use of carbon as support was evaluated also by Centeno et al. [24] and Mortensen et al. [25]. In the latter study, carbon-supported nickel catalyst was found to be practically inactive for HDO of phenol suggesting that the nickel based catalysts require a metal oxide as carrier on which the activation of the phenol for the hydrogenation might take place through heterolytic dissociation of the OH bond to facilitate the reaction. Ni-based bimetallic catalysts have been proved very active for CO bond hydrogenolysis [10,11], which is crucial for the title reaction. The aim of the present work is (i) to investigate the effect of pre-treatment conditions (reduction against sulfidation) on the behavior of carbon supported Rh catalysts for HDO of phenol (ii) to compare the catalytic performance of a carbon supported Rh catalyst with that of a Ni one (iii) to examine the promoting action of Mo on a carbon supported Ni catalyst. The catalytic activity was evaluated in the HDO of phenol because the phenolic compounds represent approx. 25% of oxygenates present in bio-oils produced by pyrolysis of lignocellulosic biomass and it is known that those compounds have shown low reactivity in hydrotreating. 2 Experimental methods 2.1 Catalyst preparation The mesoporous carbon (C; nanopowder) and a Norit RX 3-extra commercial active carbon (AC; cylindrical pellets) used as supports were supplied by Sigma–Aldrich and NORIT Americas Inc. D, respectively. Their specific surface area, total pore volume and average pore diameter of pure supports are listed in Table 1 . The Rh/C sample was prepared by the wet impregnation of mesoporous carbon (C) with Rh(NO3)3 aqueous solution. After adsorption equilibrium had been reached, the excess of water was removed until dryness in a rotary evaporator. Catalyst drying was performed in air at 60°C overnight, followed by decomposition of the Rh(NO3)3 salt under He stream 30mL/min at 400°C for 2h. Ni/AC and Mo-Ni/AC samples were prepared by impregnation of active carbon (AC). Before impregnation, carbon pellets were crushed and sieved to a particle size fraction 0.25–0.35mm, purified consecutively by refluxing several times with distilled water and dried. The Ni/AC and Mo-Ni/AC samples were prepared at 100°C by deposition-precipitation of active components on AC surface using aqueous solution containing Ni(NO3)2 or Ni(NO3)2 and (NH4)6Mo7O24 as well as aqueous ammonia as precipitating agent. Considering our previous study [26], the value of N i N i + M o = 0.77 atomic ratio was adopted for the preparation of Mo-Ni/AC catalyst. After filtration, the solids were dried and decomposed as previously. 2.2 Catalyst characterization 2.2.1 Chemical analysis The chemical analysis of the C- and AC-supported samples was performed, respectively, by atomic absorption spectrophotometry conducted on a Perkin-Elmer Optima 3310 DV inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectrometer (ICP-AES) and by T-XRF spectrometry using TXRF S2 PicoFox (Bruker) apparatus. 2.2.2 X-ray diffraction The crystal phases of the fresh reduced samples were investigated by power X-ray diffraction employing a Brucker D8 Advance diffractometer equipped with nickel-filtered CuKα (1.5418Å) radiation source. The step size and the time per step were respectively fixed at 0.02○ and 0.5s in the range of 10°≤2ϴ≤80°. The mean crystallite size was estimated using the Scherrer’s equation. 2.2.3 Raman spectroscopy Raman spectra were recorded with a Renishaw in Via Raman Microscope spectrometer equipped with a laser beam emitting at 785nm, at 310mW output power. The photons scattered by the sample were dispersed by a 1200lines/mm grating monochromator and simultaneously collected on a CCD camera; the collection optic was set at 50× objective. 2.2.4 N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms The textural properties [specific surface area (SBET ), pore volume (Vtotal ) and mean pore diameter (d)] of the fresh reduced catalysts were evaluated from nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms obtained at −196°C using a Micromeritics apparatus (Tristar 3000 porosimeter) and the corresponding software. An amount of about 100mg of a degassed sample at 250°C for 2h was used in each experiment. 2.2.5 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) XPS studies of the fresh reduced and spent catalysts were recorded using an Escalab 200R spectrometer equipped with a hemispherical analyzer, operated in a constant pass energy mode, and unmonochromatized Mg Kα (hυ=1253.6eV, 1eV=1.603×10−19 J) X-ray source operated at 10mA and 12kV. The ECLIPSE software was used to record and analyze spectra. The line of C 1s at 284.8eV (accuracy within ±0.1eV) was used as an internal standard to correlate the values of the binding energy obtained in order to normalize the charging effects appearing commonly on non-conductive samples. Each spectral region of the photoelectrons of interest was scanned a number of times to obtain a good signal-to-noise ratio. The intensity of the peaks was estimated by calculating the integral of each peak after subtraction of background and by fitting the experimental peak to a combination of Lorentzian/Gaussian lines of variable proportions. 2.2.6 Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) The morphology of under He heated catalyst precursors was studied by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) on a Hitachi Tabletop TM-1000 electron microscope, equipped with energy dispersive X-ray analysis EDX QUANTAX 50. 2.2.7 High resolution transmission electron spectroscopy (HRTEM) The spent catalysts activated by reduction or sulfidation were studied by HRTEM microscopy using a JEM 2100F microscope operating with a 200kV accelerating voltage and fitted with an INCA X-sight (Oxford Instruments). The catalysts were ground into a fine powder and dispersed ultrasonically in hexane at room temperature. Then, a drop of the suspension was put on a lacey carbon-coated Cu grid. An energy dispersive X-ray microanalysis (EDX) system was used to verify the semi-quantitative composition of the supported phases. 2.2.8 Quantification of coke deposits by TG/DTA The coke deposited on the spent catalysts was quantified by thermogravimetry (Mettler Toledo TGA/SDTA851 equipment). Each sample was previously heated up to 500°C for 0.5h in He flow (50mLmin−1) in order to homogenize coke and remove the volatile compounds. Once the sample was cooled to ambient temperature in the same flow of He, burning of coke was carried out by raising temperature to 900°C at a rate of 10°Cmin−1 in a 20% O2/He gas mixture (50mLmin−1). 2.2.9 Activity test Prior to activity tests, the Rh/C catalysts were activated by: (i) in situ reduction at 310°C for 2h with a 1:3H2:N2 mixture (50mLmin−1) or (ii) in situ sulfidation at 310°C for 2h with a H2S/H2 mixture (H2S/H2: 15/85v/v – 50mLmin−1). Ni/AC and Mo-Ni/AC catalysts were activated by in situ reduction with pure H2 (50mLmin−1) at 450°C for 2h. Hydrodeoxygenation of the phenol was performed in a high-pressure laboratory-scale set-up equipped with a down-flow fixed bed catalytic reactor. In each experiment 0.1g of catalyst was used (particle diameter: 0.25–0.35mm) and the reaction conditions were: T =310°C, total H2 pressure of 3MPa, weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) of 107.5h−1 and a H2/feed ratio of 250L(N)L−1. The liquid feed (2wt.% of phenol dissolved in decaline) was injected by a high-pressure HPLC Knauer pump into a hydrogen stream. The blank experiments demonstrated that decaline did not suffer dehydrogenation/isomerization over the catalysts studied and upon the reaction conditions adopted. The reactor effluents were condensed, and liquid samples were analyzed by a GC Agilent 6890A with a FID detector and by MS-GC (Shimadzu GM-MS QP2010) equiped with a BPX5 column (length: 50m; inner diameter: 0.22mm; thickness: 0.25μm). The total phenol conversion was calculated as its disappearance. Additionally, activities are described in terms of the specific reaction rates, calculated according to Eq. (1): (1) r = X · F m where, r represents the specific rate expressed as mole of phenol per mole of metal and per h, X the conversion of phenol, F the molar flow rate of this reactant (mol/h), and m the metal atoms per gram of catalyst (molMetal gcat −1). A commercial NiMoP/γ-Al2O3 catalyst (HR-348 from Procatalyse; S BET =164m2 g−1; and Mo, Ni and P loading of 10.7, 2.5, and 2.64wt.%, respectively) tested upon the same reaction conditions was used as reference. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the oxide and fresh reduced samples 3.1.1 Chemical and textural properties The elemental composition of the samples in terms of the Rh, Ni and Mo loadings is presented in Table 1. As seen, the synthesized samples exhibit relatively similar total metal loading (in range 2.6–3.7wt.%), which is much lower than of the commercial catalyst (13.2wt.%). SEM images (not presented) of all samples showed that the particles of carbon support (C or AC) are decorated with irregular particles of metallic species, which are seen as white particles located on the grey color support. In general, the Rh species distribution on mesoporous C support seems to be more uniform than that of AC-supported ones. This was confirmed by EDX/SEM elemental mapping. In this work, the mesoporous carbon (C) and active carbon (AC) used as supports sharply differ in specific surface areas (150 vs. 1310m2 g−1) and average pore diameter (6.4nm vs. 2.5nm) (Table 1). As a consequence, at the same metal loading (about 3wt.%), the Ni/AC and Mo-Ni/AC samples exhibit a larger SBET and total pore volume than Rh/C (Table 1). Indeed, inspection of Table 1 shows that the Rh/C sample exhibits a relatively low specific surface area (79m2 g−1) and low specific pore volume (0.17cm3 g−1). In contrast Ni/AC and Mo-Ni/AC samples exhibit very high specific surface areas (1184 and 1131m2 g−1, respectively). The numerical analysis of the adsorption data by the Barret-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method [27] indicated that the Rh/C sample exhibit larger average pore diameter (dp =8.7nm) than both Ni/AC and Mo-Ni/AC samples (dp =2.1nm and dp =2.8nm, respectively). For Rh/C, an increase of average pore diameter (from 6.4 to 8.7nm) after metal deposition onto mesoporous carbon strongly suggests micropore’s blockage. This is consistent with a larger percentage loss of specific surface area after rhodium loading onto this carrier (47.3%) with respect to Ni/AC and Mo-Ni/AC samples (9.6% and 13.7%, respectively). More information on the textural properties of oxide precursors can be obtain by analyzing shapes of N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms at −196°C (Fig. 1 ). According to the IUPAC classification, all samples exhibit type IV isotherms with H4 hysteresis loop. This type of hysteresis loop is indicative of pores of aggregates of plate-like particles forming slit-like pores [28]. However, contrary to the Rh/C, the Ni/AC and Mo-Ni/AC samples display a high nitrogen uptake at low relative pressure (P/P0 <0.1) typical of microporous solids [29]. 3.1.2 Raman spectroscopy Raman spectroscopy was used for investigating possible changes in the carbon-based catalyst support. This method is widely used to characterize basic structural properties of carbon based materials [30]. The Raman spectra of the C-supported samples after drying and/or after thermal decomposition of active phase precursor salts (thermal treatment under He) are shown in Fig. 2 . As seen, all samples exhibit the same two bands. The so-called D mode peak at around 1306cm−1 (1325cm−1 for Ni/AC and Mo-Ni/AC samples) assigned to carbon atoms with sp3 hybridization due to defects or distortion of the crystal lattice [31,32] and the G band at about 1597cm−1 attributed to an active vibration E2g of sp2 hybridized carbon atoms, known as the graphitic mode. The ratio of the intensity between the D and G bands (ID/IG) is often used for characterization of carbon supports, since the D originates from edge configurations in graphite where the planar sheet configuration is disrupted, and G provides a good representation of the sp2 bonded carbon that is present in planar sheet configurations [32–34]. The intensity ratio (ID/IG) for the Rh/C sample exhibited the higher value (1.39) among the samples studied. This indicates that carbon material used as support in the Rh/C sample possess increased fraction of sp3 -hybridised carbon defect sites in comparison to the AC used for the preparation of Ni and Mo-Ni samples. Ni/AC sample exhibited an ID/IG value of 1.27 in both cases after drying and after nickel nitrate phase decomposition. This is an indication that support-supported phase interaction does not influence the support structure. On the other hand the ID/IG value of 1.19 determined over Mo-Ni/AC dried and decomposed samples reveals that the addition of Mo-phase influences the support structure decreasing the disordered phase of the AC from the early preparation step. 3.1.3 Crystal phases The X-ray powder diffraction patterns of the fresh reduced samples are shown in Fig. 3 . All these patterns involve mainly characteristic peaks of the carbon support (JCPDS 00-003-0401). For the Rh/C sample, no peaks corresponding to the Rh phases were detected. This indicates that Rh nanoparticles are too small to be detected by the XRD technique (particle size <4nm), or they are amorphous. Concerning the Ni and Mo–Ni/AC samples besides of the support peaks two peaks corresponding to NiO at 37.27 and 62.82° (JCPDS 22-1189) are observed. The FWHM at 37.27° in the Mo–Ni/AC sample is lower than the counterpart of Ni/AC one. This indicates that the mean size of NiO crystallites is higher in the Mo–Ni/AC sample. Peaks of Ni0 are not observed probably because the most intense of them are obscured by the support peak at 43.9°. Peaks corresponding to the Mo phases were not detected. The above are in good agreement with the HRTEM results. 3.2 Characterization of fresh reduced and spent catalysts 3.2.1 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, which is a typically surface technique, allows us determining the reduction degree of metals as well as the metal-support interactions. Fig. 4 (A) and (B) shows the Mo 3d and Ni 2p3/2 core level spectra of the fresh reduced and spent AC-supported catalysts, respectively. Fig. 5 shows the Rh 3d core level of the spent Rh/C and Rh(S)/C catalysts activated by reduction and sulfidation, respectively. For all catalysts, Table 2 summarizes the peak positions in eV for the most intense photoelectron peaks. Based on the deconvolutions of the Ni 2p5/2 and Ni 2p3/2 core levels spectra using Gaussian/Lorentzian mixed functions, all Ni-based catalysts exhibit peaks due to Ni0 (about 853.0eV) [35] and unreduced Ni2+(about 856.3eV) [36]. In good agreement with XRD (Fig. 3), the NiO species remain unreduced after catalyst pre-treatment with pure H2 (450°C for 2h). The formation of Ni2O3 can be excluded because those species are reduced quantitatively to metallic Ni in H2 at 300°C, which is much lower temperature that those employed for the catalyst reduction. Considering the work by Kraus et al. [37], the presence of Ni(OH)2 species after catalyst reduction at 450°C is hardly possible. This means that other factors than formation of Ni(OH)2 species might contribute to the catalyst deactivation during time course of reaction. The presence of substantial amounts of unreduced NiO species (in range 72–89%) strongly suggest their difficult reduction due to the strong metal-support interaction [36,38,39]. The low reducibility of NiO (≈20%) was reported also for ZSM-5+Al2O3-supported Ni catalysts reduced at much higher temperature (450°C vs. 500°C). Considering the percentage of Ni0 species given in Table 2 in parenthesis, the reduction of Ni/AC is much easier than of Mo-Ni/AC suggesting a lower metal-support interaction on the former than on the latter catalyst. The low sulfidation degree of Ni species on the Mo-Ni/AC should be linked with the presence of MoO3 species on the catalyst surface. Indeed, the Mo 3d peak of fresh reduced and spent Mo-Ni/AC catalyst shows only one doublet separated (Δ=3.15eV) Mo 3d5/2 and Mo 3d3/2 spin-orbit components indicating that there are only one type of Mo species. The BE at about 232.6eV (Mo 3d5/2) corresponds to supported polymolybdate species in the highest oxidation state [40]. Considering the very low Mo loading of Mo-Ni/AC sample (0.87wt.%), the difficult reduction of MoO3 species is expected. This is because at low Mo loadings the polymolybdate MoO3 species exists mainly as in amorphous tetrahedral form having a strong interaction with support, which makes them difficult to reduce [41]. The amorphous character of Mo species was confirmed by XRD (vide supra). Finally, the surface XPS atomic ratios are compiled in Table 3 . The Rh/C, Ni/C and Mo/C atomic ratios were calculated from the corresponding peak areas normalized by sensitivity factors [42]. As seen in Table 3, the spent Ni/AC catalyst exhibits two-times larger surface exposure of Ni than its spent Mo-Ni/AC counterpart, as deduced from the higher Ni/C atomic ratio of the former sample. This is mainly due to the higher Ni loading in the first catalyst (Table 1) In addition, the comparison of the Ni/C and Mo/C atomic ratios of fresh reduced and spent Mo-Ni/C catalysts indicated a strong decrease in the surface exposure of both Ni and Mo species during reaction conditions adopted. To evaluate the location of metal particles on the support surface and/or within inner support porous structure, the ratio of the number of surface metal atoms determined by XPS to the total number of metal atoms determined by chemical analysis was calculated (Table 3). As seen in Table 3, almost all catalysts exhibited higher XPS metal-to-carbon atomic ratio than their bulk value in accordance with the fact that the metals are deposited on the support surface. However, the metal species distributions depend not only on the support but also on the type of metal, in agreement with the SEM/EDX results mentioned above. As compared with fresh reduced Rh/C, the fresh reduced Ni/AC catalyst shows a higher external surface exposure of Ni species, in good agreement with XRD patterns showing large Ni crystals on the surface of AC (Fig. 3), that are not able to be formed into the micropores of this support. The fresh reduced Mo-Ni/AC and Ni/AC catalysts present much larger NiXPS/NiBulk atomic ratio than their spent forms (21.8 vs. 6.0 and 42.4 vs 7.6, respectively). Although the migration of active phase into inner support structure or sintering cannot be precluded, it is more likely that the reactant/products strongly adsorbed on the active phase were not totally removed by degassing in the pre-treatment chamber of XPS equipment. This point will be discussed below. The Rh/C catalyst was selected to study the effect of catalyst activation: reduction against sulfidation. The experimental and the fitted spectra of the Rh3d core-level spectra of the reduced Rh/C and sulfide Ru(S)/C catalysts are shown in Fig. 5. The values of the binding energies (BE) of the peaks of Rh are listed in Table 2. For the spent Rh/C sample activated by reduction, the binding energy of Rh3d5/2 core level is 307.6eV. Thus, there is small shift of BE because the expected value for metallic Rh species is 307.2eV [43]. This BE shift may be attributed to the presence of small metal crystals trapped in the lattice of the carbon support. In this sample, the Rh3d5/2 core level spectra indicate that 71% of surface Rh species remain mainly in a reduced state (BE 307.6eV) and 29% of the Rh species is due to the presence of Rhδ+ species (BE at 309.6eV) suggesting the possible electron transfer between the metal and the oxide species. Concerning the spent Rh(S)/AC catalyst, although the presence of rhodium sulfide species is expected, no change in the BE with respect to reduced Rh/C sample was observed (307.6eV against 307.7eV). The Rh3d5/2 peaks at 307.7 and 309.7eV indicate the presence of Rh0 and Rhδ+ species, respectively [44]. Taking into account that the BE of Rh2S3 is only 1.4eV higher than the Rh0 species [43], the formation of small amount of the Rh2S3 species cannot be excluded. However, due to a broadening of the Rh 3d peak, their quantification is difficult, if not impossible. Regarding C1s binding energies of AC-supported Ni and Mo-Ni catalysts, the curve-fitting analysis reveals at least four different types of carbon atoms centered at binding energies of 284.8, 286.2, 287.8 and 289.2eV, respectively. For both catalysts, the peak centered at 284.8eV can be ascribed as due to non – functionalized sp2 carbons and some sp3 hybridized carbons (CC and CH2 CH2 ) whereas the peak at 286.2eV can be due to hydroxylated (COH) ones. Contrary to Ni containing catalysts, the Rh/C and Rh(S)/C exhibited only three C1s peaks at BE of 284.8, 286.2 and 288.2eV, respectively, confirming different nature of C species in the both types of carbon supports (AC vs. C). For all catalysts, the peak centered at 284.8eV was observed for non-functionalized sp2 carbons and some sp3 hybridized carbons (CC and CH2 CH2 ). Those for hydroxylated (COH) and carboxylate (OCO) carbons are centered at 286.2 and 288.2eV, respectively. For the Rh/C sample, the relative intensities for the sp2 no functionalized carbon (CC) and sp3 hybridized carbons (CC and CH2–CH2–), hydroxylated carbon (COH), and carboxylate carbon (OCO) are 70, 25 and 5%, respectively. For the Rh(S)/C sample, the relative intensities for the peaks centered at 284.8, 286.2 and 288.2eV are slightly different (66%, 26% and 8%%, respectively) with respect to the reduced sample. 3.2.2 High resolution transmission electron spectroscopy (HRTEM/EDX) HRTEM/EDX is used for determining the size, shape, and composition of carbon-supported phases. In the HRTEM images, supported metal particles appear as dark spots, while the support itself appears as a lighter background. Fig. 6 shows that a uniform micro-distribution of both metallic and sulfided Rh nanocrystals obtained in the mesoporous carbon particles. Chemical (EDX) analysis performed over several areas on the TEM micrographs confirmed the rather uniform distribution of Rh species on the carbon surface of both catalysts. In contrast, Ni nanocrystals deposited on the AC particles exhibited an egg-shell micro-distribution independently of the Mo existence. The statistical analysis of about 250 particles of the spent catalysts activated by reduction and sulfidation is shown in Fig. 7 . As seen in this figure, the mean particle size of the spent catalysts follows the trend: Rh/C (3.1nm)<Rh(S)/C (3.5nm)<Ni/AC (4.1nm)<Mo-Ni/AC (4.8nm). Fig. 8 illustrates HRTEM micrographs of the spent metallic catalysts. In these micrographs the metallic crystallites of Ni and Rh have been observed. In contrast Mo containing crystallites have not been detected in the Mo-Ni/AC sample. This implies an amorphous nature for the Mo-phase, in agreement with the XRD results. The combined XPS and HRTEM results demonstrated that the dispersion of Rh species on the mesoporous C (Rh/C) was higher and more homogeneous than that of Ni and Mo-Ni species supported on microporous active carbon (Ni/AC and Mo-Ni/AC): the Rh species are located in the pores of mesoporous carbon as well as on the external support surface, whereas the Mo-Ni species are mainly located on the external surface of the microporous active carbon. This more homogeneous Rh dispersion is expected considering a large difference of the pore diameter between Rh/C (8.7nm) and Ni/AC (2.1nm) and Mo-Ni/AC (2.8nm) catalysts and a low size of Rh0 particles (≈3.1nm, from HRTEM) which are able to entry the inner porous structure of mesoporous carbon. 3.2.3 Evaluation of coke In order to shed light on the catalyst deactivation, the spent catalysts were studied by temperature-programed oxidation followed by TGA technique. The weight changes during catalyst oxidation in a 20% O2/N2 mixture (TGA and DTGA profiles) are shown in Fig. 9 . As seen in this figure, C- and AC-supported catalyst show strong DTGA peaks centered at ca. 500°C and 580°C, respectively, which are characteristic of coke oxidation [45,46]. The temperature shift going from C- to AC-supported catalysts strongly suggests that the type of coke formed on the AC carrier should be more polymerized than that formed on mesoporous carbon. A temperature shift occurs also for the support combustion confirming that there are different types of carbon materials: mesoporous carbon is burned at temperature upper than 500°C whereas active carbon is burned at temperatures higher than 580°C. Thus, TPO characterization of the spent catalysts strongly suggests that the reactivity of coke strongly depends on its structure which is closely related to the morphology of the catalyst [47]. The amount of burned coke is listed in Table 4 . As seen in this table, the amount of coke follow the trend: Mo-Ni (47.6%)>Ni/AC (34.1%)>Rh(S)/C (24%)>>Rh/C (8.3%). Besides the coke formation, other possible reasons for the catalyst deactivation can be suggested (sintering of the metal particles, pore constriction, pore blockage, decrease of active phase dispersion and so on) [9]. A more detailed study of the final state of spent AC-supported catalysts was reported by us previously [46]. 4 Catalysts evaluation for phenol deoxygenetion The catalytic behavior of the synthetized catalysts was evaluated in a fixed bed micro-reactor for the HDO of phenol reaction at 310°C, P =3.0MPa and WHSV = 107.5h−1. Before reaction, the catalysts were activated by in situ reduction at 450°C with pure H2 for 2h. Time course of phenol conversion is shown in Fig. 10 (A). Inspection of this figure reveals that Ni/AC, Mo-Ni/AC and Rh(S)/C catalysts exhibit high initial activities, but they are deactivated during time course of reaction. On contrary to sulfided Rh(S)/C, the reduced Rh/C catalyst exhibited lower initial activity but very good stability during 4h time on stream. Similarly, the commercial NiMoP/γ-Al2O3 sulfided catalyst did not suffer deactivation during 4h time on stream (Fig. 10(A)). This can be explained considering much larger total metal loading of this sample with respect to all catalysts studied. At reaction time of 1h the monometallic Ni/AC catalyst is more active in HDO of phenol than bimetallic Mo-Ni/AC counterpart (Fig. 10(A)). XPS characterization of the fresh reduced catalysts reveal that this is because of its larger amount of metallic Ni0 and NiO species with respect to Mo-Ni/AC (Table 3). It is known that the metallic species are needed for the activation of H2 molecules, while metals with variable oxidation states (Ni2+ and Mo6+) are required for the activation of oxy-groups [13]. In Fig. 10(B) the intrinsic catalyst activities (expressed as mol of phenol converted per mole of metal(s) and per hour) are compared. The initial intrinsic activities (calculated by extrapolation of conversion data to zero time) follow the trend: Mo-Ni/AC>Ni/AC≈Rh(S)/C>Rh/C>NiMoP/γ-Al2O3. After 4h of reaction time, this trend is different: Mo-Ni/AC>Rh/C≈NiMoP/γ-Al2O3 >Ni/AC>Rh(S)/C. However, regardless of the reaction time, Mo-Ni/AC catalyst exhibited the highest intrinsic activity. This trend reveals that the intrinsic catalyst activity is related mainly to the nature of the active phase and not to support morphology. Indeed, although both C and AC supports sharply differ in specific surface areas (150m2 g−1 and 1310m2 g−1, respectively), this feature does not appear to be of great relevance for the catalytic response of C-supported catalysts. This is because the mesoporous C with a low SBET (150m2 g−1) possesses enough amount of OH groups which act as chemical anchorage centres for the Rh precursors [48], as confirmed by very good Rh dispersion on the mesoporous carbon (from HRTEM). As expected, the products detected in the HDO of phenol reaction were: cyclohexane (CH), cyclohexene (CHE), benzene (B) and cyclohexanol (CHO). Considering the products detected and the relevant literature [49–51], a reasonable reaction network is shown in Scheme 1 . As seen in this scheme, the HDO reaction over all synthetized catalysts occurs on through the multistep reactions consisting of metal-catalyzed hydrogenation and acid sites-catalyzed hydrogenolysis and dehydration, as it was proposed previously for C-supported noble metals [51]. H2 is dissociated on metal sites, while O-containing compounds are adsorbed and activated on either metal sites or on the cations/oxygen vacancies located at the metal-support interface [4–9]. Table 4 summarizes the selectivity data calculated at ∼30% of phenol conversion. Inspection of this table reveals that the commercial NiMoP/γ-Al2O3 sample was unique showing 100% selectivity toward O-free products (see Table 4). The HDO degree (%), which is defined as the the selectivity toward oxygen-free products, Rh/C and Ni/AC catalysts were more selective toward O-free products than Mo-Ni/AC and Rh(S)/C catalysts prepared. As expected from literature [51], all catalysts show a very low selectivity toward benzene (1–3%) suggesting that phenol HDO occurs mainly via hydrogenation reaction route being non-significant hydrogenolysis route (direct cleavage of the CO σ bond of phenol). The obtained selectivity results are in good agreement with study by Zhao et al. [51], which observed that Rh/C catalyst did not undergo direct hydrogenolisis to benzene in an aqueous-phase HDO of phenol to cyclohexane at 200°C in the presence of H3PO4. Assuming a bifunctional mechanism of the HDO reaction for all catalysts studied, a low selectivity toward O-free products implies that all catalysts exhibited larger hydrogenation than acidic function (Table 4). Fig. 10(C) shows the yields of O-free products after 4h time on stream. As seen, the yields of those products follow the trend: NiMoP/γ-Al2O3 >Ni/AC>Mo-Ni/AC≈Rh/C≈Rh(S)/C. This trend reveals that: (i) Activation by reduction of the rhodium catalyst is favored with respect to the sulfidation concerning the HDO of phenol. The large HDO activity of metallic Rh supported on mesoporous C is probably a result of the larger stability of this sample on stream conditions. Catalysts further developed from this one could be used in the final stage of bio-liquid transformation into high quality and O-free bio-oil. (ii) Although the binary Mo-Ni/AC sample showed the largest intrinsic activity (Fig. 10(B)), this catalyst exhibits a lower yield of O-products than Ni/AC counterpart and the commercial NiMoP/γ-Al2O3 sulfided catalyst. This means that both latter catalysts exhibit larger hydrogenation properties than binary Mo-Ni/AC counterpart. This behavior could be attributed to the diminution of Ni loading in the Mo-Ni/AC sample in order to retain the total metal loading equal to that in the Ni/AC. This means that more research effort is certainly needed for the development of Mo-Ni catalyst supported on a carbon support for bio-liquid transformation into high quality and O-free bio-oil. Taking into account that acidic function is needed for the hydrogenolysis of COH bonds of cyclohexanol to obtain cyclohexane and cyclohexene [39], the largest yield of O-free products obtained with Ni/AC catalyst strongly implies its relative high acidity among the catalysts studied. In turn, the large acidity of this catalyst might explain its largest deactivation during time course of reaction. This is because the coke formation can be enhanced by acidic sites and the phenols are known to be precursors of the carbonaceous deposits [9]. Indeed, the larger coke formation on the surface of Ni/AC with respect to Rh/C can be explained considering the larger acidity of the active carbon with respect to mesoporous carbon which is linked with a larger amount of OH groups of the former material. However, this explanation is no valid for Mo-Ni and Ni catalysts supported on the same AC carrier. As seen in Table 4, the amount of coke formed on Mo-Ni/AC sample is larger than that on Ni/AC. However, the former catalyst exhibits a higher stability during time course of reaction than the latter. Thus, there is no correlation between the amount of coke formed and percentage of catalyst deactivation when the catalysts are supported on the same carrier. A possible explanation for the enhancement of stability of Mo-Ni/AC catalyst with respect to Ni/AC sample should be related to the presence of surface MoOx species on the former sample. This is because the metal oxides of transition metal elements are known to exhibit strong acidic character, as it was demonstrated in many reactions, in particular in reactions involving hydrocarbon conversion [52]. In these cases, MoOx clusters might act as scavengers for coke precursors protecting the active Ni0 phase from deactivation. The development of acid sites is related to the coordinatively unsaturated Mo6+ species on the surface (Lewis acid sites) [53] and to the hydroxyl groups formed by protonating the terminal MoO or bridging COMo bonds on the carbon surface (Brønsted acid sites) [54]. 5 Conclusions The present work showed that the activation procedure of the rhodium catalyst supported on mesoporous carbon is critical for its catalytic behavior concerning the HDO of phenol. Activation by reduction is of advantage with respect to that by sulfidation. All carbon-supported catalysts demonstrated bifunctionallity in HDO reaction with hydrogenation function larger than acidic one. Rh/C catalyst activated by reduction is more effective for O-removal than partially reduced Ni/AC and Mo-Ni/AC catalysts. For all catalysts studied, the type of metal and amount of active phase (Rh0 and Ni0) played a decisive role in the target reaction. The presence of MoO3 on the surface of Mo-Ni/AC enhanced the catalyst stability acting acidic MoO3 clusters as scavengers for coke precursors. All catalysts exhibit a very strong metal-support interaction linked with their very low total metal loading (3wt.%). As a consequence, the Ni-based catalysts exhibit difficult reduction of their metal oxides. The catalyst behavior is strongly depending on the amount of metallic Ni species, which are active phases in the target reaction. coredata.dc:description: This work reports the performance of low metal loading (about 3wt.%) Rh, Ni and Mo-Ni catalysts supported on carbon in the hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of phenol. The catalytic tests were carried out in a flow microreactor at 310°C and at a total hydrogen pressure of 3MPa. A commercial NiMoP/γ-Al2O3 sulfided catalyst was used as reference. The effect of catalyst pre-treatment (reduction against sulfidation) was investigated in the case of the noble metal catalyst. The thermally treated in inert atmosphere, fresh reduced and spent catalysts have been characterized by several physicochemical techniques: chemical analysis, N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms, Raman spectroscopy, Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM), X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and High Resolution Transmission Electron Microscopy (HRTEM). The HDO of phenol was found to be favored on the bifunctional Rh/C and Ni/AC catalysts which exhibit a large amount of well dispersed metallic species (from HRTEM). Contrary to a commercial sulfided NiMo/Al2O3 catalyst, the hydrogenation of aromatic ring of phenol was favored being the CO bond hydrogenolysis a minor reaction route. Catalytic HDO of phenol over Rh/C reveal that the catalyst activation by reduction is advantageous compared to that by sulfidation. The partial substitution of Ni by Mo in the Mo-Ni/AC catalyst led to enhance of the catalyst stability but decrease of overall activity occurs due to the decrease of amount of metallic nickel species. The role of the MoO3 species in the inhibition of deactivation by coke is discussed.
coredata.dc:title: HDO activity of carbon-supported Rh, Ni and Mo-Ni catalysts
